review.title: A technical study and analysis on fuzzy similarity based models for text classification
review.abstract: In this new and current era of technology, advancements and techniques, efficient and effective text document classification is becoming a challenging and highly required area to capably categorize text documents into mutually exclusive categories. Fuzzy similarity provides a way to find the similarity of features among various documents. In this paper, a technical review on various fuzzy similarity based models is given. These models are discussed and compared to frame out their use and necessity. A tour of different methodologies is provided which is based upon fuzzy similarity related concerns. It shows that how text and web documents are categorized efficiently into different categories. Various experimental results of these models are also discussed. The technical comparisons among each model's parameters are shown in the form of a 3-D chart. Such study and technical review provide a strong base of research work done on fuzzy similarity based text document categorization.

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijdkp.2012.2201 1In this new and current age of technology, advances and techniques, the efficient and effective classification of text documents becomes a challenging and urgently needed area to categorize text documents into mutually exclusive categories. Blurred similarity provides an opportunity to find the similarity of characteristics between different documents. In this paper, a technical review of various blurred similarity-based models is given, which are discussed and compared to demonstrate their use and necessity. A tour of various methodologies based on blurred aspects of similarity is offered, showing how text and web documents are efficiently categorized into different categories. Different experimental results of these models are also discussed. Technical comparisons between the parameters of each model are presented in the form of a 3D diagram.

sections.heading: 2. THEORETICAL BACKGROUND
sections.text: In recent decades, the fuzzy classification of text documents based on similarity has attracted a lot of attention and is considered an important area of research. Various techniques, models and methods are sought to design an optimal categorization system. Such a field is not only used in small organizations, industries and enterprises, but also covers a vast community around the world. New techniques, their collaboration and research always open up a new paradigm toward advancement. Recent research studies show that fuzzy logic and its scope provide an efficient basis for text categorization, dimension reduction, selection and extraction of characteristics and similarity analyzers. Fuzzy logic is considered as a branch of logic specifically designed to represent knowledge and human thought in a way that it can be processed by a computer [3]. The main concepts of fuzzy logic are fuzzy sentences, linguistic variables, distributions of possibility, and then blurred rules.

sections.heading: 2.1. Feature Clustering
sections.text: The concept of feature clustering [10] [11] [22] - [24] improves the provision of text dimension critical solutions. It is an efficient way to compress the collected feature sets more so that the resulting data can be handled and used properly without loss. These clusters are either represented by the concept of maximum frequency in a group (or cluster) [22] [24] or can be found by a self-constructing feature clustering algorithm [23]. Feature clustering also occurs when using the pseudo-thesaurus, using each term [6] as a noun, pronoun, adverb, adjective, delimiter, etc. Researchers have shown that it helps to reduce the high-dimensional data adequately into smaller ones.

sections.text: Fuzzy sets play an important and crucial role in text categorization. They are widely recognized because many real relationships are inherently blurred. sections.heading: 2.4. Fuzzy Clustering and C-Means
sections.text: In fuzzy clustering [28], each point has a certain degree of cluster affiliation, as in fuzzy logic, rather than belonging entirely to a cluster. Therefore, points at the edge of a cluster may be in the cluster to a lesser extent than points at the center of the cluster.

sections.heading: 2.5. Fuzzy Signatures
sections.text: Fuzzy signatures [26] are used in applications and key areas that require the handling of complex structured data and interdependent functional problems, but also in specific areas where data is missing. Thus, many areas are represented in which objects with very complex and sometimes interdependent characteristics must be classified in addition to the evaluation of similarities and dissimilarities, leading to a complex decision model that is difficult to construct effectively. Due to the nature of fuzzy signatures of flexibility, it can be used for many text mining tasks, with the advantage of hierarchical structuring; therefore, the classification models of text documents can be constructed [26].

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Various research shows good results with the underlying techniques, mechanisms and methods. Experimental results provide good, fuzzy-based text classification with high accuracy. These models focus on new types of different classification problems and techniques. Therefore, these research studies and their collection contribute to providing information on advanced fuzzy classification, related models and techniques. Analytical verification provides a simple summary of sources in an organizational pattern and combines both summary and synthesis to give a new interpretation of ancient material. Therefore, it aims to review the critical points of current knowledge about research work, including substantive results as well as theoretical and methodological contributions. Furthermore, its experimental results and parametric data are sufficiently described and compared independently from each other. Such comparative studies and technical analysis diagrams provide a strong basis to understand the use of fuzzy finds and the related concerns. Various experimental results have thus proven to be good logic models for the use of fuzzy in whole areas of classification and fuzzy fields.
